awd_abstract_narration:
Microfluidic systems employ hair-sized channels to analyze fluids in credit card sized devices. Microfluidics has been shown to improve the accuracy, speed, and cost of medical tests, drug discovery, and chemical testing, but every new medical test needs to be custom designed, making microfluidic chips expensive. 3D printing (3DP) has the potential to make custom devices quickly and inexpensively. The problem with combining microfluidics and 3D printing is that an engineer with deep knowledge of the 3DP process is needed to do each design. In contrast, engineers have developed microelectronic design tools that design chips automatically. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will investigate using the principles applied in microelectronic design to produce automated design tools that enable medical technicians to design custom microfluidic devices that can be ordered and reliably 3D printed.  Ultimately, custom tests might be designed, ordered, printed, and sent to a clinic or doctor’s office. The microfluidic devices could become a critical part of healthcare, food safety, chemical testing, and biodefense.

The use of design automation approaches and software can greatly improve the efficiency of design, validation, and manufacturing of microfluidic devices. Current CAD and simulation tools must be customized for each application, making them slow and expensive, and  microfluidic chips often require redesign due to imperfect manual placement and routing.  To overcome these challenges, several key scientific barriers need to be overcome to utilize design automation for 3D printed microfluidics. Specifically, there is a need to emulate the complexities of fluid dynamics in design automation simulation software, perform 3D placement and routing, and automate the post-processing of 3D printed microfluidic devices. The research team will develop a physics-based fluid dynamics framework for SPICE simulations coded in Verilog-AMS that handles the complexities of fluids, a placement and routing approach to build 3D designs using current open-source EDA tools with a multilayer approach, and automated systems to remove uncured resin in printed devices. The approach will be validated by using the tools to design, optimize, fabricate, and test DNA analysis devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project successfully learned the techniques need to demonstrate a series of software tools that took as an input a chemical assay protocol and automatically generated a 3D printed solution to implement the assay. Along the way, the software definined components to implement the assay, did a presimulation of the layout, used software and tools specifically design for laying out transistors and other electronic computing chips (called Electronic Design Automation) to rapidly design and layout the microfluidic devices, resimulated the devices to ensure they still met the needed assay requirements, and then generated a 3D printing file based on the autmoated layout. The file was then printed, the device cleaned out to be ready for use, and then tested.  Thus, a complete "idea" to "physical device" process was demonstrated for the first time for microfluidic devcies.

Several other important technical outcomes occurred during this project. The tools were also used to demonstrate basic 3D layout of microfluidic devices by stacking microfluidic components. Some of these outcomes were:

We developed and demonstrated a software environment that can build a mathematical model and simulate anautomatically laid-out microfluidic device.

We developed techniques for the optimization of automatically laid out devices to meet different optimization criteria, such as minimal coonection lengths, smallest chip area, and fastest operation.

We designed, built, tested, and demonstrated a practical post-processing instrument to automatically remove unpolymerized resin from microfluidic devices printed using stereolithography methods.

These outcomes are particularly significant in that they show the first demonstration of using EDA tools (which have already been extensively developed) to generate microfluidic devices. We have also for the first time demonstrated a complete toolchain for automated design, layout, simulation and printing of microfluidic chips. Using these EDA tools lead to some somewhat unexpected opportunities. First, EDA tools have different optimization criteria than may be desired for microfluidic devices, and there are multiple optimization criteria that need to be balanced. Using these EDA tools and our developed interface for implementing microfluidic devices in these tools, we can now layout and simulate (at least for the relatively simple chips tested so far) hundreds/thousands of microfluidic devices in a short period of time (less than an hour, often a few minutes on a ?normal? computer) to find the devices that optimize for different requirements (shortest connections, smallest chip area, most accurate functionality, etc.). We now also have an automated flushing system that will allow us to rapidly postprocess 3D printed chips, meaning that these devices could be used by a amateur user without needing to understand or implement complex postprocessing steps.

We are now in a position to make rapid process in developing a an automated microfluidic layout ecosystem, including exploring optimization in 3D space, working with complex assays, expanding our component library, optimizing the layout of these generated chips, and exploring the limits of 3D printing of microfluidic chips.

Furthermore, it has become clear that rapid development can be achieved now that the basic toolchain has been developed and interoperability between software components has been established. We can  generate thousands of designs in an day and compare them for optimal layout since microfluidic devices are much simpler than electronic systems, which should allow for unique development opportunities. 

The project outcomes also included the following:

Training of 3 PhD students and 3 undergraduate students including women and minority students.

Development of new materials for microfluidics and design automation courses. 

Software tools available on GitHub for general use.

Software tools that can be used by other researchers, engineers, and the public to develop and 3D print microfluidic devices rapidly and efficiently.

 


Last Modified: 07/31/2023
Modified by: Bruce K Gale

  • The overall concept of microfluidic design automation as demonstrated in this project.
    Bruce Gale

    Microfluidic Design Automation Concept

    Brady Goenner

    Microfluidic Device Layout
